abstracts.cdata!:
The project has only partially met its
            objectives and was therefore rated as unsatisfactory. The
            key lessons learned from this project include: 1) More
            realistic project implementation periods are required in
            situations where more than one implementing institutions is
            involved and/or where the public bureaucracy is known to be
            particularly cumbersome; 2) More analytical work is needed
            for the treatment of the institutional aspects in the
            formulation of irrigation projects. 3) More efficient
            supervision approaches are required in situations where the
            Bank's field supervisions by Bank staff are limited. 4)
            The setting up of a proper monitoring & evaluation
            system is crucial to an efficient project implementation and
            should take place at the very beginning of the project. 5)
            The use of heavy machinery for civil works in small farms is
            problematic and should be considered with great care. 6) In
            cases where loans are closed with important project
            activities remaining to be carried out, and where most of
            the benefits stated at appraisal could still be achieved,
            the Bank should formulate an action program with the
            Government for the purpose of reinforcing the implementation
            plan set at appraisal.

5079156.majtheme: Rural development,Environment and natural resource management

abstracts.cdata!:
The proposed project consists of the
            following components: (a) institutional dvelopment -
            provision of the means to plan and monitor agricultural
            development in the region, including establishment of a
            monitoring system for water resource use and water and soil
            quality, strengthening of the applied research, training
            institutions and extension services, and creation of an
            agency for operation and management of the drainage
            infrastructure, and development of a Project Management Unit
            to coordinate project implementation; (b) rehabilitation of
            oases - drilling of wells, provision of pumping equipment
            and construction of irrigation and drainage networks; (c)
            on-farm development - agriculture improvement and supply of
            inputs; and (d) studies, technical assistance and training -
            preparation of development plans, feasibility and
            environmental assessments for future investments in the
            sector, provision of technical assistance and training.
